tossups.question: Jacob Robinson rebutted this work in the book And the Crooked Shall be Made Straight. A 2011 book by Bettina Stangneth cites the Sassen documents to challenge this book's claims. This book critiques the "bad history and cheap rhetoric" in opening statements by Gideon Hausner. This book discusses a perpetual "joiner" of such organizations as the YMCA and Wangervogel, who claimed to follow the categorical imperative but "had ceased to live according to Kantian principles." This book criticizes a man whom the author witnessed inside a glass cage in a courtroom for his repeated use of "stock phrases and self-invented clichés." This book cites that man, who claimed to be "just following orders," as exemplifying the "banality of evil." For 10 points, name this book about a Nazi official's trial by Hannah Arendt.

tossups.question: The speaker of this poem "walk[s] on" after making "the wall of shadow draw back." This poem's speaker describes how "the fruited boughs burn, pecked at by birds" and wonders "how you could contain me" in "the cross of your arms!" Although it remains in couplets, the assonance and fourteen-syllable alexandrine verse used in this poem are not included in its English translation by W. S. Merwin. This poem's speaker says that "like a jar you housed the infinite tenderness" before exclaiming, "How terrible and brief was my desire of you!" This poem's final line laments the "abandoned one" because "it is the hour of departure." This poem, which opens with the line "the memory of you emerges from the night around me," repeats that "in you everything sank!" For 10 points, name this poem by Pablo Neruda that follows his Twenty Love Poems.
tossups.formatted_answer: "The Song of Despair" [or "La canción desesperada"]
tossups.answer: "The Song of Despair" [or "La canción desesperada"]

tossups.question: The "Holy Maid of Kent" Elizabeth Barton was executed for prophesying ill fortune from this woman's marriage. The title of "Marquess of Pembroke" was created for this woman. Eric Ives decried the "monster legend" spread by Nicholas Sanders about this woman. Elizabeth Somerset testified that this woman committed adultery with Flemish musician Mark Smeaton. Thomas Wyatt's poem "Whoso List to Hunt" may have been inspired by infatuation with this woman, who was said after her death to have twelve fingers and three breasts. This person's headless ghost supposedly haunts the Tower of London. This woman's execution was prominently supported by Thomas Cromwell. Affection for this woman may have caused the "King's Great Matter", which led to the annulment of a marriage to Catherine of Aragon. For 10 points, name this second wife of Henry VIII (“the eighth”).
tossups.formatted_answer: Anne Boleyn
tossups.answer: Anne Boleyn

tossups.question: In this substance, an electron-hole plasma violates the Wiedemann-Franz law. This substance's conduction and valence bands meet at sets of points labeled K and K' ("K prime"). For this substance, the fact that a factor of four multiplies the quantity "Landau level plus one-half, all times e-squared over h" provided evidence of a Berry phase of electrons behaving masslessly due to an anomalous quantum Hall effect. Nanoribbons of this substance created by "unzipping" its more space-filling analogue also exhibit ballistic transport, making it a perfect semi-metal with zero band gap. It is usually created by exfoliation, following Geim and Novoselov's isolation of this material via "micromechanical cleavage" with Scotch tape. For 10 points, name this honey-comb lattice, a one-atom thick allotrope of carbon.
tossups.formatted_answer: graphene [do not accept "graphite,"; do not accept "carbon nanotubes" or "nanotubes"; do not accept "carbon"]

tossups.question: This artist painted the faint image of a putto on a squat column below the Madonna in his earliest depiction of the Mystical Marriage of Saint Catherine called the Bardi Altarpiece. This artist was driven to insanity believing he could turn wooden flowers into gold leaf while painting the choir vault of the Santa Maria della Steccata, which was imitated by Girolamo Bedoli. A painting by this student of Corregio which survived the Sack of Rome depicts a sleeping in a bush dreaming of a contorted John the Baptist pointing up to the Virgin and Child behind him. tossups.question: An iconic garment from this region whose name translates to "warm place" may have been influenced by the Fair Isle technique. Bill Holm published an early book on this region's art while working as the curator of its Burke Museum. Carvers would handpick blocks from hidden kwawhlhal (KWA-hul) quarries for argillite carvings exclusive to this region. Ovoids and U-forms are used to establish positive and negative space by practitioners of this region's formline art. Ceremonial button blankets appliquéd with dentalium shells are worn at traditional feasts in this region. tossups.question: In the King James Version, this book contains the only instance of God's name "JAH," and a verse popular among Jehovah's Witnesses for praising "Thou, whose name alone is JEHOVAH." In Eastern Christianity, three stases make up each of the twenty kathismata of this text. In Islamic tradition, this extant text is traditionally considered largely equivalent to the holy book revealed between the Tawrat and Injil, which is called the Zabur. An "imprecatory" chapter of this book lends the Rastafari Melodians' "Rivers of Babylon" its title. Many michtams and maskils appear in this book, which was the first book printed in British America in a "metrical" version nicknamed for the Bay Colony. Scottish architect Benny Priteca designed neo-classical "Pantages (pan-TAY-jeez) Greek" style buildings for these events. Keith. Managers of these events sent notes on "politeness" standards in blue envelopes. tossups.question: A "false" type of this phenomenon can affect computational results based on upwind schemes. The rate of this phenomenon appears in the denominator of the Péclet (PAY-clay) number. In the mathematically simplest case for this phenomenon, its effects are proportional to the complementary error function of "x over root t," as can be derived from the prototypical parabolic PDE. A quantity describing this phenomenon is equal to mobility times Boltzmann's constant times temperature, by Einstein's relation. This phenomenon's flux is proportional to minus its namesake coefficient, by Fick's first law. This stochastic phenomenon, which is driven by Brownian motion, has types including osmosis. tossups.question: In 1969, this author's presumed skull was reinterred at a Coxwold estate after it was allegedly only saved because it was recognized by a Cambridge anatomy student when this author's body was stolen from a grave. This author's correspondence in support of abolitionism helped bring Ignatius Sancho to prominence. This author's writings to Eliza Draper were published under the name of a character created by this author, who ends a book mid-sentence while touching a chambermaid in France. The monograph On Noses, by Hafen Slawkenbergius, is discussed in a novel by this author in which a mistake with a pair of forceps causes a character's nose to be flattened by Dr. Slop. tossups.question: A hoard of 130 "curse tablets" discovered in 1979 are dedicated to a Celtic deity associated with this activity. Cult worshippers honored one deity who performed this action annually in Kanathos. A piglet was sacrificed and then eaten after one instance of this action performed during the Eleusinian mysteries. While doing this action, a son of Hermes and Aphrodite was merged with the nymph Salmacis. One warrior was inspired to use yarrow stalks to heal soldiers after gaining strength from performing this action in a place filled with yarrow. Scylla was transformed into a monster when Circe poisoned her while she was doing this action. Daedalus tricked King Minos into performing this action when discovering him in Sicily, causing Minos to be scalded to death. tossups.formatted_answer: bathing [accept synonyms like washing oneself; accept being dipped in the River Styx]

A piece written for this musician opens with a section inspired by the address of the Curtis Institute of Music that this performer attended from age 10. tossups.question: While living in this state, an author wrote stories that were rediscovered in the 2020 collection Hitting a Straight Lick with a Crooked Stick. In a story set in this state, the title character dies after slipping on a circle saw, believing that he was haunted by a black bobcat who represented Joe Kantz. A story set in this state ends with a woman sitting under a chinaberry tree, waiting for her husband Sykes to die of a rattlesnake bite. A trip to this state led to an author to collect seventy folktales from it in a collection prefaced by her mentor Franz Boas. Folktales from this state were collected in the collection Mules and Men. tossups.question: The first person to hold this post was formerly the leader of a metalworkers' union who led a 1950 general strike and arson campaign known as "Red Sky." That holder of this post was accused of rigging the 1970 Miss World pageant in favor of Jennifer Hosten and repressed political opponents with a secret police called the Mongoose Gang. Herbert Blaize was the first person to rise to this position as the result of free elections. tossups.question: These are the main ecological zones studied by Nalini Nadkarni, who gave a TED Talk titled for "conserving" them. Lianas (lee-AR-nas) can form "bridges" between organisms in these zones. Production is proportional to one minus the negative exponential of a quantity often measured for these zones using hemispherical photography. As their ecosystems spread laterally, these zones have a decreasing value for the L·A·I, a type of "area index," due to their namesake "closure." In these ecological zones, adjacent organisms display mutual disengagement by maintaining a gap between them in a phenomenon called "shyness." This zone is found directly below the emergent layer and directly above the understory. tossups.question: In an introduction to Marcel Mauss, this thinker attacked the former's use of "mana" as "void of meaning and thus apt to receive any meaning" in passage coining "floating signifier." This thinker's theory of mythology is summarized in the statement that "myth is language." This thinker was married to the anthropologist Dina Dreyfus, whose eye infection ended her time studying the Nambikwara with him. In opposition to Vladimir Propp's focus on the individual folktale, this thinker argued that the fundamental units of narrative are mythemes. tossups.question: If "X sub n" describes a flip of a biased coin, then this mathematician names the variable (q / p)X n (“q over p to the power X sub n”), which is their namesake martingale. This mathematician's article "Annuities of Lives," about the normal distribution of mortality, may have inspired the story that they exactly predicted their own death. Near the start of a play set in this city, a character declares that this city is "no more" and says, "lift thy head, unhappy lady, from the ground" in self-reflection. A character enters holding two torches and singing a frenzied wedding song in a play set in this city, which may be a response to the massacre at Melos. Rhesus is set in this city, as is a play that ends with the herald Talthybius carefully balancing his shield as he brings a woman the maimed body of her baby son Astyanax (ass-TAI-an-ax). tossups.question: The elder Richard Henry Dana's doubts about this poem's authenticity prompted him to say, "No one, on this side of the Atlantic, is capable of writing such verses." The addressee of this poem will join the "millions in those solitudes" and "mix for ever with the elements." This poem describes how each "will chase his favorite phantom" and how "the rude swain turns with his share, and treads upon" the "sluggish clod." This poem advises to "go forth, under the open sky, and list to Nature's teachings," to "take the wings of morning," and to "pierce the Barcan Wilderness." When joining "the innumerable caravan," this poem advises to be not "like the quarry-slave at night" but like "one who wraps the drapery of his couch about him and lies down to pleasant dreams." The Méduse was shipwrecked on its way to this modern-day country's port of Saint-Louis (sahn-loo-ee). The House of Slaves is located on the former slave hub of Gorée Island in this country.

parts: Name this contemporary musician whose jazz-inflected hip-hop albums include To Pimp a Butterfly and DAMN.

The first piece by a Black composer to win the Pulitzer was George Walker's Lilacs, which was premiered by this "Big Five" orchestra under conductor Seiji Ozawa. In the summer, it performs at Tanglewood.

Longtime Pulitzer juror Gunther Schuller coined this term for music that combines jazz and classical elements, exemplified by the works of William Grant Still and the Miles Davis album Sketches of Spain.
answers: Kendrick Lamar [or Kendrick Lamar Duckworth; prompt on Kendrick; prompt on K-Dot]

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the western blot, a technique used to identify a specific protein in a sample. For 10 points each:
parts: The first step of a western blot is to run one form of this procedure on a polyacrylamide base. Generally, this procedure separates macromolecules based on mass using a current.

The second step of a western blot is transferring the gel to a membrane made of PVDF or this compound. This compound, made by combining nitric and sulfuric acids with cloth, was used as an explosive during World War I.

The third step of a western blot is binding the target protein to primary and secondary antibodies. The secondary antibody is often conjugated to this chemiluminescent enzyme derived from the root of a vegetable.

bonuses.leadin: While in the Rusty Spoon, this company's employee Kurt Mondaugen tells the story of witnessing the Herero uprising of 1922. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this fictional company, which may be inspired by its creator's time working for Boeing in the 1960s. In another novel, Clayton Chiclitz leads this company's infantile shareholders in a singalong before the protagonist meets its disillusioned employee Stanley Koteks.
Yoyodyne prominently features in The Crying of Lot 49, a novel by this postmodernist American author.
Pynchon introduced Yoyodyne in this debut novel, which interleaves Benny Profane's meetings with the Whole Sick Crew with Herbert Stencil's search for the mysterious title figure.

bonuses.leadin: Keith Haring's tribute to this artist depicts a pile of crowns, in reference to this artist's motif of placing crowns over boxers or musicians like Charlie Parker. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this artist who created SAMO with Al Diaz.
Basquiat was photographed with this other artist wearing boxing gloves. This Pop artist produced silkscreens of Marilyn Monroe at "the Factory."

Basquiat's introduction to art came from reading this book while recovering from a broken arm. Richard Tibbits is the current artist for this book, whose first edition was illustrated by Henry Vandyke Carter.

bonuses.leadin: In the Ivory Coast, these people marched in 1949 to a prison in Grand Bassam, where many were attacked by French troops during an anti-colonial demonstration. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this general group of people who often served as bodyguards for Muammar Qaddafi (MOO-ah-mar gah-DAF-ee) and made up a military regiment called the Dahomey Amazons.

The 1956 Women's March in this city protested against pass laws and was co-led by anti-apartheid activist Helen Joseph. This city is named for the Boer leader during the Great Trek who was victorious at the Battle of Blood River.

In 2003, thousands of women marched through the town of Ziguinchor (zee-gan-SHAWR) in this southern region of Senegal to demand peace talks during a civil war with the MFDC, which is mostly composed of members of the Jola ethnic group.
answers: women [or ladies; or girls; or brides; or wives; or females or other synonyms]
formatted_answers: women [or ladies; or girls; or brides; or wives; or females or other synonyms]

bonuses.leadin: Unlike similar devices used in tuned circuits, a high Q-factor need not be possessed by these devices, whose "common-mode" type is used to stop electrical interference from power supplies. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these specific devices often used as part of filters. These devices block high-frequency alternating current while letting through direct current and lower-frequency alternating current.
Chokes are a type of these circuit components, which store energy in a magnetic field and have a namesake quantity measured in henries.
Chokes work because their value for this quantity increases with frequency. Resistance equals the real part of this quantity, and reactance equals the imaginary part of this quantity.
answers: chokes [or choke coils or common-mode chokes; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, inductors]
formatted_answers: chokes [or choke coils or common-mode chokes; prompt on, but DO NOT REVEAL, inductors]

bonuses.leadin: Idiosyncratically, the reflexive and reciprocal types of these words are the only words considered anaphors in generative grammar. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this part of speech whose personal subtype includes the English words "he," "she," and "they."

An antecedent has this property relative to an anaphor if the antecedent c-commands it and they corefer. In the sentence "Chris negged himself out of the game," the word "Chris" has this property relative to "himself."

Noam Chomsky's Lectures on Government and Binding argues that children do not have to learn the universal "principles" of all languages, but only adjust to their first language's "parameters" in an extension of this Chomskian argument that children cannot learn grammar from their limited exposure to natural language alone.

bonuses.leadin: As a nightclub performer, this actress often wore a Wonder Woman outfit and performed the song "I Enjoy Being a Girl." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this veteran and actress whose gender reassignment surgery in the early 1950s was highlighted by a New York Daily News frontpage. She chose her new name in honor of her Danish endocrinologist, Christian Hamburger.
A calypso song about Christine Jorgensen was performed by this musician, whose stage name was "The Charmer." After converting to Islam, this man abandoned music and organized the Million Man March.
An Ed Wood movie that was inspired by Christine Jorgensen co-starred Bela Lugosi, who may be better known for playing this vampire in a 1931 film that was based on a Bram Stoker novel.

bonuses.leadin: This poet asked, "Do you know the land where the lemon trees bloom?" in "Mignon," included in a bildungsroman whose protagonist joins the Tower Society. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this author whose time in Italy inspired his Italian Journey, Venetian Epigrams, and Roman Elegies.

This country's Romantic-era poem "Exile Song" responds to Goethe's question with, "My land has palm trees where the thrush sings." Giuseppe Ungaretti taught Italian at this country's São Paulo University.

This poet wrote that "a glimpse of yellow lemons" causes "the golden trumpets of radiance" to "thunder their songs" in "Lemon Trees," the first poem from the collection Cuttlefish Bones. Unlike Ungaretti and Quasimodo, he denied being a member of Italian Hermeticism.
answers: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe [The novel is Wilhelm Meister's Apprenticeship.]
Brazil [Federative Republic of Brazil; or República Federativa do Brasil]

bonuses.leadin: These landforms, which are called tombolos when they link the mainland to an island, can develop when the end of a sand spit rejoins the mainland. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these structures formed by longshore drift in which a ridge of sediment, usually sand, is built up to near the sea surface offshore. If they cease to be submerged, they form barrier islands.
Sandbars can sometimes form in these regions where a river splits into many channels as it nears its mouth. These regions are named for their resemblance to a Greek letter.

The longshore drift that builds up sandbars is sometimes named for this adjective, which names the zone of the sea nearest to the shore. The zone of this name includes the intertidal zone and stretches from the high water mark to permanently submerged areas.
answers: sandbars [or bars or shoals or sandbanks or gravelbars]
formatted_answers: sandbars [or bars or shoals or sandbanks or gravelbars]

bonuses.leadin: Jerome claims the Church of the Nativity was briefly converted into a grove dedicated to this deity, whom women weep for in Ezekiel 8. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this shepherd deity who names the fourth month of the Hebrew calendar. This lover of Inanna, who spends half the year in the Underworld in her place, was syncretized with Adonis.
As Dumuzid's story was converted into the Greek tale of Adonis, Innana became this goddess whose other lovers include Butes and Anchises, the father of Aeneas.

Innana was worshiped with this epithet also used for a goddess to whom Hebrew women bake cakes in the Book of Jeremiah. Give the usual three-word English translation of this royal epithet, also used to translate the Marian epithet Regina caeli.

bonuses.leadin: Ernst Mandel revived interest in Kondratiev waves through his PhD dissertation on this period. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the common English two-word for this period. Its mode of production produces a "cultural logic" of "skepticism towards metanarratives" according to Frederic Jameson.
Western Marxists like Jameson object to the contention of such Orthodox Marxists as Mandel that the mode of production constitutes an economic "base" on which this theoretical construct lies.
"Late capitalism's" coinage is credited to Werner Sombart, who led the "Youngest Historical School" of economic theorists in this language in which Marx wrote.
answers: late capitalism [accept late-stage capitalism; Spatkapitalismus; accept Postmodernism: the Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism]
formatted_answers: late capitalism [accept late-stage capitalism; Spatkapitalismus; accept Postmodernism: the Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism]

bonuses.leadin: Lewis Swegles revealed to Secret Service agent Patrick Tyrrell the plot to steal this object, which was to be exchanged for money and engraver Benjamin Boyd's release from custody. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this object that the counterfeiter "Big Jim" Kennally planned to have stolen from Oak Ridge Cemetery in 1876.

Detectives from this man's namesake agency prevented the theft of Lincoln's corpse. "We Never Sleep" was the motto of this man's detective agency, which helped break up the Molly Maguires and battled steel workers in 1892 during the Homestead strike.

In 1861, Pinkerton learned that members of the Knights of the Golden Circle planned to kill Lincoln when he arrived at a train station in this city. A few months later, the Pratt Street Riots occurred in this city.
answers: the corpse of Abraham Lincoln [or answers describing the dead body or remains of Abraham Lincoln; prompt on partial answers]
Allan J. Pinkerton [or Pinkerton National Detective Agency; or Pinkertons]
formatted_answers: the corpse of Abraham Lincoln [or answers describing the dead body or remains of Abraham Lincoln; prompt on partial answers]
Allan J. Pinkerton [or Pinkerton National Detective Agency; or Pinkertons]

bonuses.leadin: A play featuring a crucified chicken and live turtles being thrown into the audience, Sacramental Melodrama, was inspired by this genre. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this genre of theater that inspired the Panic Movement. Antonin Artaud (ar-TOH) laid out a theory of this genre in The Theater and Its Double.

As in Sacramental Melodrama, this playwright interacted with the audience by instructing white masks to be handed out in his play The Blacks. This playwright drew inspiration from the Theater of Cruelty for the play The Maids.

Carol Rosen called this Genet play a Theater-of-Cruelty staging of the "dark side of the human soul." In this play, the patrons of Madame Irma's brothel dress up as authority figures during a revolution.

bonuses.leadin: The Barong dance that originated in this province's Gianyar region traditionally ends with Barong's triumph over the demon queen Rangda. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this province whose puras include Besakih Temple. Sang Hyang Widhi Wasa, or Acintya, is the supreme god of a Hindu tradition native to this island province.
Per Indonesian legal restrictions, Balinese Hinduism is considered monotheistic due to equating Acintya with this "ultimate reality" that dualistic Hindus contrast with the individual soul, or atman.

Prambanan, Indonesia's largest Hindu temple, was likely built by the Sanjaya dynasty to rival Sewu and this other nearby complex. In Java, the Sailendra dynasty built this largest Buddhist temple in the world.

bonuses.leadin: Solid samples can be analyzed directly by combining this technique with attenuated total reflection. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this analytical technique which can detect behavior like "wagging" and "stretching" in the "fingerprint region."
The nuclei of samples observed using IR spectroscopy exhibit this type of oscillatory motion, due to bonds effectively acting like springs.
To directly use solid samples in IR spectroscopy, they are often crushed alongside this oil to produce a mull, which is spread out into a thin film before being analyzed.

bonuses.leadin: With engineers from Intel, this composer created the Neural Network Synthesizer, which was supplemented with 16 audio channels for use in a piece for Merce Cunningham's Enter. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this electronic composer of the installation Rain Forest, better known for premiering Pierre Boulez's second piano sonata and the pieces Music of Changes and 4'33" (“four minutes, thirty-three seconds”).
Tudor premiered most of the piano music by this avant-garde composer and partner of choreographer Merce Cunningham, including the aforementioned 4'33".

Mauricio Kagel introduced Tudor to the bandoneon and to this style of music. The bandoneon was played in this style by Anibal Triolo, whose bandmate Astor Piazzola went on to play bandoneon and compose pieces in this style's "nuevo" form.

bonuses.leadin: Joseph Atwill's widely discredited book Caesar's Messiah alleges that this historian wrote most of the Gospels as part of a conspiracy involving Pliny the Elder. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this client of the Flavians who wrote Against Apion. He led the Galilean forces in a revolt which became the subject of his history The Jewish War.

According to Josephus, the three main Jewish denominations of the Second Temple Period were the Pharisees, Sadducees, and this strict third group. A celibate commune of this denomination may have lived in Qumran (koom-RAHN).
The Essenes were long regarded as the authors of these texts discovered in 1946 by Bedouin shepherds looking for a lost goat in caves near a namesake body of water.

bonuses.leadin: This author praised "the man who considers...what good or evil he has done, and what judgement his soul will receive after its passing" in his five-line "Death Song." For 10 points each:
parts: Name this mentor of Alcuin of York. He preserved the legend of Caedmon and his namesake hymn in a history written in Jarrow.

Caedmon's Hymn, possibly the oldest surviving English poem, was one of the oldest poems to use this poetic device. This repetitive device, also used in the Poetic Edda, typically replaced rhyme in Old English poetry.

Along with saints' lives, these works make up the majority of surviving Old English prose. Examples of these works include one that Wulfstan punningly titled "Lupi ad Anglos," as well as Jonathan Edwards's much later "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God."

bonuses.leadin: The shape formed by joining these points by straight lines is sometimes called the Kasner polygon. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these points that divide a line segment exactly in half.

This theorem states that the polygon formed by joining the midpoints of the sides of any quadrilateral is a parallelogram. Its namesake also names a theorem about the additivity of torque, which is often proven geometrically.

Varignon's theorem still applies even for quadrilaterals described by this term, which means their four points do not all lie in the same plane. Similarly, two lines are described by this term if there is no plane that contains both of them.
